markdownRemark.html:
React Testing Library

  • this helps simulate how user interacts with application
  • avoiding implementation details when testing is the motto of react testing library
  • it helps get rid of boilerplate code, e.g. handling mounting and cleanup of components so that tests can execute independent of each other
  • it builds on top of dom testing library

Basics

  • use import { render, screen } from '@testing-library/react' to render and query respectively
  • rendering optionally returns some stuff - const { container, unmount } = render(<Counter />)

Jest Dom

when we import @testing-library/jest-dom (done by default in create-react-app), it improves the assertions that we can make, to make code and error messages in failing tests much more readable

// replace this
expect(message.textContent).toBe("Current count: 0");
// with this
expect(message).toHaveTextContent("Current count: 0");

Searching Elements

  • because of screen readers and accessibility issues, using the following syntax is better - 
    const increment = screen.getByRole('button', { name: /increment/i });
const message = screen.getByText(/current count/i);
    inspect an element and go to the accessibility tab under the elements tab
  • we can add our own custom queries
  • getBy, findBy and queryBy - get and find will throw an error if the element isn’t found while query returns null. all of them throw an error if more than one match is found, which is when we can use getAllBy, findAllBy and queryAllBy. we can use await to wait for changes in dom with the find variant. cheatsheet
  • we can use the above with ByLabelText, ByText, ByPlaceholderText, ByDisplayValue (form element value), ByAltText, ByTitle (title attribute or svg title tag), ByRole (aria role) and ByTestId (data-testid attribute)

Events

  • fireEvent is already wrapped with act
  • assume our code had onMouseDown instead of onClick. because of such nuances, it is better to use userEvent over fireEvent. userEvent uses fireEvent behind the scenes 
    import userEvent from '@testing-library/user-event'

userEvent.click(increment);

Miscellaneous

  • use screen.debug() to get an idea of what the ui looks like, or console.log(document.body.innerHTML)
  • a good way of generating fixture data - 
    function getLoginData(overrides) {
  return {
    username: faker.internet.userName(),
    password: faker.internet.password(),
    ...overrides
  }
}
  • we might want all state updates to be flushed before react tests continue. to do this, we may have to wrap certain functionality around act
  • note - our tests do not run in the browser. they run in node where a browser is simulated using jsdom. this can have some limitations sometimes, for which we might need to use polyfills / move our tests to e2es
  • to wait for something - await waitFor(() => screen.getByRole('alert'))
  • another option is await waitForElementToBeRemoved(...)

Mock Service Worker

  • msw - a library which helps with mocking of requests to server 
    import { rest } from "msw";
import { setupServer } from "msw/node";

const server = setupServer(
  rest.post(
    "https://auth-provider.example.com/api/login",
    async (req, res, ctx) => {
      if (!req.body.password) {
        return res(ctx.status(400), ctx.json({ message: "password required" }));
      }
      if (!req.body.username) {
        return res(ctx.status(400), ctx.json({ message: "username required" }));
      }
      return res(ctx.json({ username: req.body.username }));
    }
  )
);

beforeAll(() => server.listen());
afterEach(() => server.resetHandlers());
afterAll(() => server.close());

test("server error", () => {
  // override behavior
  server.use(
    rest.post(
      "https://auth-provider.example.com/api/login",
      async (req, res, ctx) => {
        return res(ctx.status(500), ctx.json({ message: "something went wrong" }));
      }
    )
  )
  // ... remaining code
});
    now, the requests that the components make are forwarded to the handlers we passed to setupServer

Snapshot Testing

  • inline snapshot testing - instead of hardcoding the values manually, we can rely on snapshot testing so that the values get updated automatically when changes are made. this snapshot testing can be done for the element’s html itself, or even for instance, the text content inside it 
    // we write this
expect(screen.getByRole("alert").textContent).toMatchInlineSnapshot();

// the tests update our code to this automatically
expect(screen.getByRole("alert").textContent).toMatchInlineSnapshot(`"password required"`);
// in case of conflicts
// there is also an update snapshot link in the cli
// which we just need to click to update our code

Deferred Promise Trick

  • this is a trick we can use when writing tests - 
    function deferred() {
  let resolve, reject;
  const promise = new Promise((res, rej) => {
    resolve = res;
    reject = rej;
  });
  return { promise, resolve, reject };
}

// usage
test("test", async () => {
  const { promise, resolve } = deferred();
  
  // ...
  
  promise.then(() => {
    // do some task
    // this functionality will be triggered
    // only when the promise is resolved
  });
  
  // ...

  resolve();
  await promise;
});

Mocking Modules

import { useCurrentPosition } from 'react-use-geolocation'

jest.mock("react-use-geolocation");
// now, the function exports from the module are jest mocks

test("test", async () => {
  let data, setData;
  function MockUseCurrentPosition() {
    [data, setData] = React.useState([]);
    return data;
  }

  // create mock
  useCurrentPosition.mockImplementation(MockUseCurrentPosition);
  render(<Location />);

  expect(screen.getByLabelText(/loading/i)).toBeInTheDocument();
  await act(() => setData([fixture]));
  expect(screen.queryByLabelText(/loading/i)).not.toBeInTheDocument();
});

Testing Hooks

  • the hook - 
    function useCounter({ initialCount = 0, step = 1 } = {}) {
  const [count, setCount] = React.useState(initialCount);
  const increment = () => setCount(c => c + step);
  const decrement = () => setCount(c => c - step);
  return { count, increment, decrement };
}
  • the test - 
    import * as React from "react";
import useCounter from "../../components/use-counter";
import { act, renderHook } from "@testing-library/react";

test.each`
initialCount | step | countOne | countTwo | countThree
${0}         | ${1} | ${0}     | ${1}     | ${0}
${4}         | ${1} | ${4}     | ${5}     | ${4}
${0}         | ${3} | ${0}     | ${3}     | ${0}
`("useCounter works when initialCount=$initialCount and step=$step",
  async ({ initialCount, step, countOne, countTwo, countThree }) => {
    const { result } = renderHook(useCounter, { initialProps: { initialCount, step } });

    expect(result.current.count).toBe(countOne);
    await act(result.current.increment);
    expect(result.current.count).toBe(countTwo);
    await act(result.current.decrement);
    expect(result.current.count).toBe(countThree);
  });
